title: Style Guide for Python Code
text: Defines widely used conventions for writing readable Python code, including naming conventions, formatting guidelines, and recommendations for comments and docstrings.

title: The Zen of Python
text: A collection of aphorisms that capture Python’s design philosophy, emphasizing readability, simplicity, explicitness, and pragmatic tradeoffs.

title: Docstring Conventions
text: Specifies conventions for writing docstrings, including one-line vs multi-line structure, summary line expectations, and stylistic guidance to support tooling and readability.

title: Version Identification and Dependency Specification
text: Standardizes Python package versioning semantics (e.g., pre-releases, post-releases, dev releases) and how versions should be compared for dependency resolution.

title: Type Hints
text: Introduces a standard syntax and ecosystem conventions for optional static typing in Python, including annotations, generics, and expectations for type checkers.

title: A build-system independent format for source trees
text: Defines a standard, backend-agnostic interface (hooks) for building Python distributions, enabling frontends to build wheels/sdists without hard-coding a specific build system.

title: Specifying Minimum Build System Requirements for Python Projects
text: Introduces declaring build-system requirements (e.g., build backend and dependencies) in pyproject.toml so tools can install what’s needed to build a project reliably.

title: Storing project metadata in pyproject.toml
text: Standardizes how core project metadata (name, version, dependencies, entry points, etc.) should be represented in pyproject.toml for consistent tooling across the ecosystem.

title: Structural Pattern Matching
text: Proposes structural pattern matching for Python, describing match/case syntax, pattern forms, binding rules, and semantics for matching on object structure.

title: Syntactic formalization of f-strings
text: Formalizes f-string syntax to simplify parsing and maintenance, tightening the language specification and reducing special-case handling in implementations.
